case_name: Yeshwant, Suraj Lal, Brahmanand Tiwari, Rupchand and Bhadu alias Ramkishore v. State of Maharashtra

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 28/29, 1969 of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in Criminal Appeal No. 139 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 175 of 1969 and 90 of 1970. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 28/29, 1969 of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in Criminal Appeal No. 139 of 1968.

facts.text: The appellants Yeshwant, Suraj Lal, and Brahmanand Tiwari were convicted under Section 302 read with Section 34 Indian Penal Code for the murder of Sukal and sentenced to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, Yeshwant, Suraj Lal, and Brahmanand, Tiwari were companyvicted under Section 302 read with Section 34 Indian Penal Code for the murder of Sukal and sentenced to life imprisonment.

facts.text: The appellants Rupchand and Bhadu alias Ramkishore were convicted under Section 307 read with Section 34 Indian Penal Code and sentenced to seven years rigorous imprisonment for assault on Zingu.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants Rupchand and Bhadu alias Ramkishore were companyvicted under Section 307 read with Section 34 Indian Penal Code and sentenced to seven years rigorous imprisonment for having made a murderous assault on Zingu who escaped and lived to depose about the attack upon him and the murdered man, Sukal, his relation and companypanion.

facts.text: Sukal and Zingu were waylaid and attacked by five persons at about 2.30 a.m on 15-9-1966 at Marartola of Village Kati near an electric lamp post.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the prosecution case, that Sukal and Zingu, while returning from a fishing expedition, were waylaid and attacked by five per-sons, one of whom was armed with an axe, with which he killed Sukal, and another with a knife, with which he stabbed Zingu cc., at about 2.30, a.m on 15-9-1966, at a place called Marartola. of Village Kati., near an electric lamp post.

facts.text: Zingu PW 8 is an eye witness, the injured survivor.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence also. disclosed, that apart from Zingu  P.W. 8 , the injured in, there were two more eye witnesses, Babaji  P.W. 17  and Jiwan  P.W. 18 , who came from the direction opposite to that of the victims.

facts.text: Babaji PW 17 and Jiwan PW 18 are eye witnesses who came from opposite direction.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence also. disclosed, that apart from Zingu  P.W. 8 , the injured in, there were two more eye witnesses, Babaji  P.W. 17  and Jiwan  P.W. 18 , who came from the direction opposite to that of the victims.

facts.text: Zingu extricated himself from assailants and fled crying for help to house of Jainarain 200 feet away.

anchor.surface_text: Zingu  P,W. 8  is said to have managed to, extricate himself from his assailants with a jerk or push and to have fled crying for help. He also stated that, while escaping, he saw Babaji  P.W. 17  companying from a side road with a lantern in his hand.

facts.text: Dr. Narsing Galole PW 2 attended to Zingu and saw Sukal unconscious near lamp post.

anchor.surface_text: Zingu rushed into the house of Jainarain situated at a distance of about 200 feet from the lamp post. Then, Dr. Narsing Galole  PW 2 , a Medical practitioner., who was sent for, came and attended to the injuries of Zingu after having seen.

facts.text: Zingu told Dr. Galole that he was caught by Rupchand and assaulted by Suraj; Sukal caught by Yashwant, Bhadya Master and Tiwari attacked Sukal.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Galole said that Zingu told him I was caught by Rupchand and I was assaulted by Suraj Sukal, was near me. He was caught by Yashwant and Bhadya Master and Tiwari attacked Sukal.

facts.text: Dr. Galole lodged First Information Report at 7.05 a.m. on 15-9-1966 at Police Station, Gondia.

anchor.surface_text: The Doctor also lodged a First Information Report at 7.05 a.m. on 15-9-1966 at Police Station, Gondia, in which it was stated that Zingu had said that he had been beaten by Suraj Koshti while Rupchand Koshti had held him,

facts.text: Sessions Judge of Bhandara acquitted the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals, by special leave, are directed against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay-allowing an appeal of the State of Maharashtra against the, acquittal of the appellants by the Sessions Judge of Bhandara.

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed state appeal and convicted appellants.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals, by special leave, are directed against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay-allowing an appeal of the State of Maharashtra against the, acquittal of the appellants by the Sessions Judge of Bhandara.

facts.text: Chandanlal PW 12 heard Zingu name Yeshwant, Suraj, Tiwari for Sukal; Bhadya Master and Rupchand for himself.

anchor.surface_text: He deposed that Zingu had said Yeshwant and Suraj eight hold of Sukal and Tiwari gave him blows. Bhadya Master caught hold of me and Rupchand gave me blows. The Statement was in. accord with the companysistent statements of the three eve witnesses at the trial.

facts.text: Zingu's purported dying declaration recorded at 7.30 a.m. on 15-9-1966 before Taluka Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: His purported dying declaration made ,it 7.30 a.m. on 15-9-1966 at Gondia Hospital, before a Taluka Magistrate, was put to him to bring out inconsistencies.

facts.text: Dr. Kale PW 7 examined Zingu at Gondia Hospital and found serious injuries.

anchor.surface_text: The trump card, however, of the defence was the statement of Dr. Kale  P.W. 7  who had examined Zingu and admitted him into the Gondia Hospital and found the following injuries on him Incised wound trangular in shape 4 cm. by lung deep left scapular area.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds evidence of identity of Brahmanand Tiwari doubtful and acquits him.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that Brahmanand Tiwari appellant is entitled to the benefit of the doubt emerging from the unsatisfactory nature of evidence as to his identity.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds convictions of other four appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that we think that the case against four out of the five appellants is established beyond any reasonable doubt. But, we doubt whether the identity of the fifth man, who was certainly there, is satisfactorily established as that of Brahmanand Tiwari.

facts.text: Chandanlal was Sarpanch of Gram Panchayat of Kati since 1966; Harlal brother of Yeshwant was previous Sarpanch.

anchor.surface_text: Chandanlal was Sarpanch of the Gram Panchayat of I Kati since 1966. He admitted that Harlal, the elder brother of Yeshwant, was the Sarpanch until 1966, and that Chandanlal was his Deputy Sarpanch.

facts.text: Sukal deceased was a candidate at the panchayat election.

anchor.surface_text: Chandanlal also said that Sukal deceased had also been a candidate at the election.

facts.text: Blood stained dhoti recovered from Yeshwant's house on 15-9-1966, human blood group B but not matching victims.

anchor.surface_text: Some clothes believed to have been stained with blood were recovered by the Police on 15-9-1966 from the houses of Rupchand, Yeshwant and Bhadu and, on 19-9-1966, from the house of Brahmanand Tiwari.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted based on Dr. Kale's evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Relying implicitly upon the evidence of Dr. Kale, the Trial Court had companye to the companyclusion that Zingu must be a deliberately untruthful witness, or, at least, a witness who had been persuaded by others to believe that the five accused had waylaid Sukal and Zingu.

facts.text: High Court reassessed evidence and convicted.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances stated above, the High Court was, in our opinion, quite right in reassessing the prosecution evidence from a companyrect angle.

facts.text: Bhadu had contusions explained by fall from bicycle; Rupchand contusion on forehead.

anchor.surface_text: Then, there were some companytusions on the body of the appel- lant Bhadu and a companytusion on the forehead of Rupchand approximating in duration the time which had elapsed between the occurrence and their examination.

facts.text: Incident during night of symbolic Marbat carrying by caste of Babaji and Jiwan.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court itself had believed that Babaji was a natural witness of the locality whose presence at the spot was explained by the fact that it was the night during which a symbolic Marbat  representing a companypse  had to be carried during the night by a person belonging to the caste of Babaji and Jiwan.

arguments.claim: Krishna Govind Patil distinguished; does not require acquittal of all if one doubtful

anchor.surface_text: In Krishna Govind Patils case  Supra  this Court held that, where four persons were charged under Section 302 read with s. 34, I.P.C., the effect of finding that three of them, who were specially indicated as the other participants, were entitled to the benefit of doubt,

arguments.claim: Jagir Singh supports conviction under s.34 where common intention proved despite individual roles hard to prove

anchor.surface_text: In Jagir Singhs case  Supra , it was pointed out that Section 34 I.P.C., is intended to meet a case where members of a party act in furtherance of a companymon intention of all but it is difficult to prove the part played by each of them individually.

arguments.claim: Case against four appellants proved beyond reasonable doubt; acquit only Brahmanand

anchor.surface_text: The result is that we think that the case against four out of the five appellants is established beyond any reasonable doubt. But, we doubt whether the identity of the fifth man, who was certainly there, is satisfactorily established as that of Brahmanand Tiwari.

arguments.claim: Sections 147 and 149 IPC possibly applicable but cannot convert acquittal at this stage

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, if five persons. are lying in wait for two to pass and then pounce upon them so that three are engaged in attacking one and two attack the other, it may be difficult to hold, as the High Court has done, that Sections 147 and 149 I.P.C. would be inapplicable.

arguments.court_reasoning: No reason to reject merely for election involvement; trial court rejected conspiracy suggestion

holdings.text: The case against four out of the five appellants (Yeshwant, Suraj Lal, Rupchand, Bhadu) is established beyond any reasonable doubt under Sections 302/34 and 307/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that we think that the case against four out of the five appellants is established beyond any reasonable doubt. But, we doubt whether the identity of the fifth man,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eyewitness evidence of Zingu, Babaji, Jiwan credible and corroborated; Dr. Kale rejected; s.34 applies despite one doubtful identity; distinguished precedents.

holdings.text: Brahmanand Tiwari is entitled to the benefit of the doubt due to unsatisfactory evidence on his identity as the axe-wielding assailant.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that Brahmanand Tiwari appellant is entitled to the benefit of the doubt emerging from the unsatisfactory nature of evidence as to his identity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Flawed identification parade (farce); unknown to witnesses; confusion in Zingu's mind; no reliable corroboration; absence from attendance register unproved.

holdings.text: Doubt as to identity of one participant under Section 34 IPC does not require acquittal of others charged under Section 302/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that this decision, which depends upon its own facts, as criminal cases generally do, lays down any general principle that, where the identity of one of the participants is doubtful, the whole case must end in acquittal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Krishna Govind Patil fact-specific, distinguished; evidence shows fifth man existed with common intention; Jagir Singh supports s.34 for group liability.

holdings.text: High Court correctly reassessed prosecution evidence in appeal from acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances stated above, the High Court was, in our opinion, quite right in reassessing the prosecution evidence from a correct angle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court erred in relying on interpolated Dr. Kale evidence; correct principles observed; reappraisal justified by erroneous assumptions.

holdings.text: Dr. Kale's evidence and medical record unreliable due to deliberate interpolation and must be ignored.

anchor.surface_text: we have no hesitation in agreeing with the High Court that the statement, put in Zingus mouth by Dr.Kale, could not have been correctly recorded by Dr.Kale and it had to be totally ignored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obvious addition of 'not' in different ink during cross-exam; post-dying declaration; no witness explanation; deliberate distortion.

holdings.text: Zingu's purported dying declaration unreliable due to confused state of mind.

anchor.surface_text: The so-called dying declaration, extracted as a result of questions put to him, gives a good indication of his rather confused state of mind, which did not mean that he was untruthful.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inconsistencies (Mukadam Patel then guest); Zingu did not recollect; serious condition; not sufficient to demolish eyewitnesses.

holdings.text: Test identification parade was a farce and unreliable for identifying unknown assailant.

anchor.surface_text: The identification proceeding was, therefore, rightly described by the Trial Court as a farce. As we have already observed, the confusion with which Zingus mind must have been cluttered,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Police brought accused to court; no similar bearded men; only 5 others; witnesses saw tape possibly only at parade.

holdings.text: Sections 147 and 149 IPC may be applicable to facts of five persons waylaying two victims, but cannot convert acquittal at this stage.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts suggest unlawful assembly/rioting; but accused acquitted below; no conversion in appeal.

precedents.citation: Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra 1

anchor.surface_text: Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra 1

precedents.case_name: Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: where four persons were charged under Section 302 read with s. 34, I.P.C., the effect of finding that three of them, who were specially indicated as the other participants, were entitled to the benefit of doubt, it was not possible to convict the fourth accused under Section 302 read with Section 34 I.P.C.
precedents.cited_holding: There is no a single observation in the judgment to indicate that persons other than the said accused participated in the offence, no is there any evidence in that regard.

precedents.citation: Jagir Singh v. State of Punjab  2

anchor.surface_text: Jagir Singh v. State of Punjab  2

precedents.case_name: Jagir Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 34 I.P.C., is intended to meet a case where members of a party act in furtherance of a common intention of all but it is difficult to prove the part played by each of them individually.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal of Brahmanand Gokul Prasad Tiwari and acquit him of all the charges levelled against him. He shall be released forthwith unless wanted in some other companynection. The appeal of the four remaining appellants is dismissed and their convictions and sentences are maintained.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal of Brahmanand Gokul Prasad Tiwari allowed and he is acquitted of all charges. Appeals of the four remaining appellants dismissed and their convictions and sentences maintained.

edges.explanation: The holding directly addresses and resolves the issue of whether doubt as to one participant's identity under Section 34 IPC necessitates acquittal of all others.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that this decision, which depends upon its own facts, as criminal cases generally do, lays down any general principle that, where the identity of one of the participants is doubtful, the whole case must end in acquittal.

Accordingly, we allow the appeal of Brahmanand Gokul Prasad Tiwari and acquit him of all the charges levelled against him. He shall be released forthwith unless wanted in some other companynection. The appeal of the four remaining appellants is dismissed and their convictions and sentences are maintained.
